description.narrative:
In line with SO1 of the HRP, the project focuses on food security in Nangarhar and Kunduz. These provinces were selected based on vulnerability, need, and presence of Oxfam#s partners. Districts will be selected based on accessibility, coverage by other actors, and the impact of returnee influx. Oxfam has been implementing cash-based food security projects in both Nangarhar and Kunduz, fundedby SIDA, DRA, UNOCHA CHF and Oxfam Australia, from which learning is used. Oxfam will build on established coordination with authorities, international organizations, and the private sector.
Needs and market assessments demonstrate a gap in income and capacity to secure immediate food and other needs. According to Oxfam#s Emergency Market Mapping <(>&<)> Analysis (EMMA) conducted under DRAI in Nangarhar March 2017, daily wages have fallen from 290 to 250 Afs daily (4 euros to 3 euros) and vulnerable people are finding nearly 30% less days of work per month. Also, the EMMA shows housing rent has increased from a monthlyaverage of 4,100 in March 2016 to 5,250 Afs. Returnee families are under severe economic stress, with the Oxfam Households Emergency Assessment Tool assessment conducted in March 2017 showing that 71% of the families don#t have any food stocks; 19% have one week#s supply. Income was reported to have decreased by more than 50% upon return to Afghanistan and most families are carrying 2 to 3 months of income worth of debt.
There is a vibrant commodity market in both provinces that can support additionalneeds arising from increased number of people in terms of food and shelter/NFI materials. Therefore, a cash-based programme is suitable. DRAII will alter our approach to multi-purpose cash grants in line with HRP recommendations.
The proposed projectisbased on the positive findings and approaches used for targeting undocumented returnees, host communities and conflicted affected people. DRAII will use the same approach but improve through a slightly different response. The project will reach 2,320households (16,240 individuals): # 1,100 undocumented Afghan returnee families who receive little assistance from other actors in Nangarhar # 220 most vulnerable host families in Nangarhar # 1000 conflict affected families in Kunduz

participating-org.narrative: The Afghan Development Association (ADA) was established in 1990 with the purpose of improving agricultural productivity in rural Afghanistan. Agricultural areas have suffered considerably as a result of almost 24 years of civil war in the country. Theirrigation system of canals and karezes (small water tunnels), on which large parts of agrarian land depend, were damaged or destroyed, or goneinto disuse after years of neglect. The consequences of the civil war include the displacement of large numbers of people and severe disruption of the economy and livelihoods of numerous poor families. ADA has concentrated its efforts in the southern and western regions of the country. Given the relative security and stability in these areas during Taliban rule,thedisplaced and refugee population of the region has been gradually returning from surrounding areas and countries. The drought prevailing for the last three years has, however, slowed down the repatriation process to some extent. The returning populationis in need of continued support to facilitate their re-integration. ADA has developed a multi-sectoral, integrated rural development package that includes the rehabilitation of irrigation systems, horticulture development, agricultural inputs (such as fertilisers, improved seed varieties, tools), veterinary training, health education, vocational training, and environmental conservation. Oxfam Novib has provided support to ADA for Integrated Rural Development Projects for several years entailing thefollowing aspects of development: encouraging and facilitating return of refugees; rehabilitating and developing rural infrastructure including farm activities; creating employment and livelihood opportunities; facilitating socio-economic reintegration; and ensuring the participation of local communities in the rural rehabilitation activities. Major components covered with Oxfam Novib support have included: the rehabilitation of rural infrastructure; food security; water supply; and vocational training. Theprojects have served tens of thousands of families. All these services were found useful in the direction of accomplishing broader objectives of alleviating poverty and fostering peace in Afghanistan.
